answers: magnetic field [prompt on B or H]
vector potential [prompt on A; prompt on partial answer]
magnetization [or magnetic polarization; prompt on M] <Rombro>
parts: Name this quantity. The integral of this quantity over a closed loop equals mu-nought times the enclosed current according to Ampère's law.

For a vector field such as the magnetic field, the field can be decomposed into a sum in which one of the terms is the curl of this quantity. The gauge fixing condition for the Coulomb gauge requires the divergence of this quantity to be zero.
The B-field is equal to mu-nought times the quantity "H plus this value." It equals the magnetic dipole moment per unit volume, and its curl gives the current density.
Name this village, the setting of a play in which the Stage Manager narrates the lives of such people as Emily Webb and George Gibbs.
Grover's Corners is the setting of this Thornton Wilder play that typically uses no stage decorations or scenery during productions.

During the third act of Our Town, dialogue reveals that many characters have died in between the acts. This alcoholic has died after hanging himself in the attic. His epitaph is not words, but rather symbols.
Name this war fought between a member of the house of Montfort and the house of Blois. It ended after the Battle of Auray.
The War of the Breton Succession was a phase of this larger, very lengthy conflict that began when the British monarch Edward III instituted a claim to the French throne.
The sixth French monarch of this name defeated a Flemish uprising at the Battle of Cassel, but was less successful against the English in the Hundred Years' War, suffering defeats at Sluys and Crecy.
Acemoğlu's book Why Nations Fail compares inclusive institutions with oppressive institutions described by this term, such as North Korea.
Acemoğlu is currently employed by this university. Robert Solow and Paul Samuelson were two longtime faculty members at this university.

Acemoğlu's breakout paper claimed that countries that engaged in this practice only developed locations where diseases were relatively rare. Thus, European countries that engaged in this practice made few infrastructural developments in Central Africa.

Name this character who desperately tries to warn the people of Sighet, shouting that he does not want money or pity but only to be listened to. He believes that God saved him so he could warn the villagers.
Moshe the Beadle appears in this acclaimed 1960 Holocaust memoir by Elie Wiesel.
This Italian Jewish author of The Periodic Table described his experience in the Auschwitz concentration camp in his Holocaust memoir If This Is a Man.

answers: five-prime cap [or 7-methylguanylate cap; or m7G cap]
parts: Name this metal whose namesake response proteins bind to IRE sites in the transcripts of proteins involved in its metabolism, such as ferritin and the transferrin receptor.
An IRES (I-R-E-S) sequence permits translation independent of this post-transcriptional structure added to the end of mRNA. The initiation factor eIF4E binds to this 7-methyl-guanylate structure.

IRE1 (I-R-E-one) initiates this signaling pathway by unconventionally splicing XBP1 mRNA to yield a transcription factor that upregulates ERAD genes. PERK phosphorylates eIF2-alpha to halt the cell cycle in this process.
Name this Italian architect who wrote the first theoretical text on perspective, De Pictura, and updated a Vitruvius text in his Ten Books on Architecture.

Alberti's original design for the Basilica of Sant'Andrea in this city lacks a transept, dome, and choir. Giulio Romano both designed the Palazzo del Te, and painted the frescoes contained therein, in this northern Italian city.

Although Alberti proclaimed these building elements to be the most noble, they are completely absent from his design for the façade of San Sebastiano, also in Mantua. Alberti often used the colossal and Corinthian orders of these support structures in the facade of Sant'Andrea.
Name this god who supposedly disappeared from the world by walking on water westwards into the Pacific Ocean.
Viracocha was one of the chief gods revered by this South American civilization, who created representations of Viracocha at Ollantaytambo and Cuzco.

In a different story, Viracocha was the progenitor of the first Incan Manco Capac, whose most prized possession was a golden object of this type. A god named after this type of object is shown in the Gateway of the Sun in Tiwanaku and was worshiped by medieval residents of the Cook Islands.
This composer was a student of Charles Gounod (goo-NOH) when he wrote his Symphony in C, which he suppressed due to similarities with his teacher's Symphony in D. He wrote the opera Carmen.
This highly self-critical composer published his Symphony in C, but destroyed all sketches of a planned second symphony. He wrote the ballet La Péri (pay-REE) and the opera Ariadne and Bluebeard.
This composer of a neoclassical Symphony in C also wrote the single-movement Symphonies of Wind Instruments as a memorial to Claude Debussy and omitted violins from his Symphony of Psalms.
Name this group of American-educated economists in Indonesia. During the Suharto regime, they promoted the liberalization and deregulation of the country's economy.

The Berkeley Mafia is frequently compared to a similar group of economic advisers whose policies were adopted by Augusto Pinochet. That group was known as the "Boys" from this place, where they had studied.
Pinochet took power after a 1973 coup in this South American country.

answers: hillside letters [or any other answer indicating that they are letters of the alphabet; or specific answers like rock letter or painted letter]
parts: Identify these mountainside geoglyphs common in the American West, where they are frequently erected to represent high schools or colleges. The University of Utah and Brigham Young University are both home to early examples of these.
The fourth hillside letter built was an M atop Mount Zion, built by and overlooking this state's School of Mines in its city of Golden.

Another hillside letter taking the shape of an M is atop Mount Sentinel overlooking this state's flagship university in Missoula. This state also has hillside M's in Butte and Bozeman to represent some of its other public universities.

answers: Madonna with the Long Neck [or Madonna and Child with Angels and St. Jerome; or any translation that mentions Madonna and a long neck]
Château de Fontainebleau [or Palace of Fontainebleau] <Shimizu>
parts: Name this painting whose title woman towers over five angels bearing gifts and holds an enormous baby Jesus on her lap.

Parmigianino's Madonna with the Long Neck and Bronzino's Venus, Cupid, Folly and Time are key examples of this artistic style that emerged between the Renaissance and Baroque, which employs serpentine poses and elongated body parts.

Francis I invited painters like Primaticcio and Rosso Fiorentino to decorate this building, which eventually lent its name to a separate school of Mannerism. This building was the original home of a Benvenuto Cellini sculpture of a nymph and a stag's head.

answers: elliptic curves [do not prompt on or accept "ellipse"; do not accept or prompt on "elliptic functions"]
parts: The conjecture involves the rational points on these mathematical objects, which are used in cryptography. A correspondence between these objects and modular forms was the basis of the Taniyama–Shimura conjecture, a key ingredient in the proof of Fermat's last theorem.

The conjecture gives a specific value for the first coefficient of this series for an elliptic curve. This kind of power series, which includes Maclaurin series, is a local approximation of an analytic function with coefficients equal to the kth derivative of the function at some point divided by k-factorial.
The conjecture remains unresolved for groups for which this quantity is greater than one. For a matrix, this quantity is equal to the dimension of the vector space spanned by its columns.

answers: John Frum movement [or John Brum movement; prompt on cargo cults]
United States of America [or the USA; prompt on America]
parts: Name this movement that believes a certain figure will return on February 15. In regions like Tanna, followers of this movement built numerous landing strips and typically advocate rejecting Western culture.
The name "John Frum" may refer to someone named John, saying he is from this country. Many servicemen from this country were stationed in the Pacific during World War II to fight Japan.

The John Frum movement, like the Ghost Dance movement and the Heaven's Gate group, is this type of movement that predicts a major event that will totally transform society. Christians who follow such movements emphasize the reign of Jesus after the Second Coming.

answers: Monmouth Rebellion [or the Revolt of the West; or the West Country Rebellion]
parts: Name this 1685 revolt. After its failure, many participants were either executed or banished in the trials called the Bloody Assizes.
The target of the Monmouth Rebellion, James II, was eventually overthrown in the Glorious Revolution and replaced by this husband of Mary. He was the third English ruler with his name.
James and his predecessor, Charles II, were previously targeted in a 1683 plot in which conspirators planned to hide an ambushing force in this mansion.

answers: Dream of the Red Chamber [or The Story of the Stone; or Hong Lou Meng]
Chinese [or Classical Chinese; or Literary Chinese; or vernacular Chinese; do not accept "Mandarin"]
parts: Name this novel in which the protagonist, born with a piece of jade in his mouth, is forced by his family into an arranged marriage, causing his cousin to waste away and die of grief.
Dream of the Red Chamber is one of the Four Great Classical Novels of this language. It was used to write Romance of the Three Kingdoms.
Near the end of the novel, Baoyu is guided through a dream by this type of person, whom Baoyu is destined to accompany. Earlier, this type of person had given a prized golden locket to Baochai.

answers: proton [or hydrogen; or H-plus; or H]
parts: Name this reaction whose first step involves oxidative addition of zinc into the alpha carbon–halogen bond.

After that first step, an ester enolate is generated, which is the nucleophile in the reaction. Enolates are usually generated by the removal or migration of this group from a carbonyl compound in a tautomerization step.
Ester enolates more commonly react with other esters to generate beta-keto-esters in this reaction. Its intramolecular variant is called the Dieckmann condensation.

answers: St. Crispin's Day speech from Henry V
"Once more unto the breach, dear friends" [do not accept other answers] <Sy>
parts: Name this speech whose speaker imagines his soldiers standing "a tip-toe" in years to come while others "hold their manhoods cheap." It is given to rouse the English army before a battle against the French.
The St. Crispin's Day speech is given before the Battle of Agincourt by the title monarch in Henry V, a history play by this author.
The third act of Henry V opens with Henry giving a speech at the siege of Harfleur, which begins with these seven words.
Name this Black Panther leader from Illinois killed in a 1969 police raid. He coined the phrase "rainbow coalition," which was later used by a Jesse Jackson organization.
Fred Hampton's death was a direct result of this organization's program COINTELPRO, which was overseen by director J. Edgar Hoover.

After the death of Fred Hampton, this group issued a "declaration of a state of war." This group, which bombed buildings across the country, was originally a faction of Students for a Democratic Society.

Tanaquil selected this son of the servant Ocrisia as the next king of Rome in part because of a fiery halo around his head. In some stories, Tanaquil also arranges his conception by a ghostly phallus that rose out of the palace hearth.
Aeneas claims to have seen his son's head harmlessly burst into flames while recounting his escape from Troy at the court of this queen of Carthage, who falls in love with him.
The only moment in the Aeneid to feature this daughter of Latinus is when her hair catches on fire as an omen. This future wife of Aeneas was originally promised to Turnus.
Name the occupation of the husband of Trina, who wins five thousand dollars in a lottery. He ultimately meets his end alongside Marcus in Death Valley.
That dentist is the title character of this Frank Norris novel. The final image of this novel is of the title character handcuffed to Marcus' corpse in the sweltering desert.
Frank Norris' 1901 novel The Octopus is about the clash between wheat farmers and this industry, a mode of transportation also prominently seen in the novel Atlas Shrugged.
